issues.description: The problem statement refers to the web layer class as "PersonController" (describing the Web Layer as containing PersonController), but both the template and the solution provide the REST API class named PersonResource (PersonResource.java). This naming mismatch between the description and the provided code can confuse students who look for a class named PersonController to implement or inspect the REST endpoints.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the naming consistent. Either update the problem statement to refer to the REST class as PersonResource (so it matches the template and solution), or rename the provided REST class in the template and solution to PersonController so it matches the description. Prefer updating the textual description to refer to PersonResource if the instructor intends to keep the current code names.

issues.description: The problem statement describes the web layer class as `PersonController`, but both the template and solution repositories implement the REST endpoints in a class named `PersonResource`. This mismatch can cause students to search for or expect a `PersonController` class that does not exist in the provided code, producing unnecessary confusion when they try to map the problem description to the template implementation and tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a consistent identifier across artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement to refer to `PersonResource` (recommended, minimal change) so it matches the template and solution code and tests, or (B) rename the REST class files in the template and solution to `PersonController` (and update their constructors/usages) if the project convention should be 'Controller'. Ensure tests and all references are updated accordingly.
